title: Part 3
content:
Part 3

THE CHILDREN HERE weren't taught many rules that would help them survive in this world.

However, there were several strict regulations.

These hadn't changed even in the latter half of the time we were five.

7:00 AM.

"Time to wake up."

With an inorganic mechanical voice announcement, the alarm went off without a second's discrepancy, and in that small room, we began to wake up.

Before getting up, staff would enter the room, and the electrodes attached were removed.

Then, immediately after getting up, a health check was conducted.

What was unfolding before our eyes was a hectic yet commonplace routine.

After checking for any changes in height or weight, we would go to the bathroom.

Urine tests were conducted once a month, and at the same time, a small amount of blood was drawn.

After the tests, the staff left without exchanging any greetings.

Then we hydrated and performed thirty minutes of some basic training to warm up our bodies.

After recording our daily physical data such as grip strength, everyone entered the training room at the same time, and we would fulfill the set quotas, separated by gender. There wasn't an option for what would happen if we didn't meet our quotas.

It was predetermined that everyone would meet it.

Those who couldn't comply wouldn't be allowed to enter this room from the next day on.

By the time all these procedures were completed, it was 8:00 AM.

Our breakfast, focused on nutrition, had evolved from early childhood to be more efficient with supplements and nutrition blocks.

Whether it was tasty or not.

Whether I liked it or not.

It didn't matter, as always.

We ate the food in the order they were served.

That was all.

After we finished our meal, the day's curriculum would start.

The subjects varied widely, starting with language arts and mathematics, and it also included economics and political science. With brief breaks in between, this repeated until noon.

For lunch, we ate a similar menu to breakfast, and the curriculum resumed in the afternoon.

After studying at our desks until 5:00 PM, we began physical education.

Everything ended at 7:00 PM.

During this time, we had never once spoken voluntarily.

After we ate dinner, bathed, and finished our physical examination, it was 9:00 PM.

Then, for the first time, a time for us to talk, what we called a meeting, was provided for us to reflect on the day.

It was a conversation that took place in a small space just for the children, without any of the educators present.

However, we couldn't freely choose the topics.

How we felt about that day's studies and how we dealt with it.

It was a time to organize and carefully examine what we had learned.

The adults wouldn't interfere unless they recognized it as unnecessary chatter.

We were also permitted to remain silent, regardless of whether we would profit or lose from it, as long as we followed the rules.

It only lasted thirty minutes, but I never felt like actively speaking; I would always just listen to their conversation. Even though the children were allowed to talk among themselves, our conversations were overheard by the adults.

This exchange was undoubtedly part of the curriculum.

However, there was no specific quota assigned.

Though, it was probably a measure to draw out the children's true feelings.

If they were to clumsily set a quota, the conversation would naturally be directed toward fulfilling it.

At 9:30 PM, we were sent back to our rooms.

After using the bathroom, we were obligated to lie down in bed by 10:00 PM.

Electrodes were attached, and the lights were turned off.

Medical checks were always required.

No matter the day, 365 days a year, there was always time set aside to check on the state of things for that day.

That was the end of the day.

From the point we woke up to the point we went to bed, that was our educational policy.

Everything was scheduled down to the minute.

That was a day in the White Room.

It was a world that didn't change for an entire year.
